I've been anticipating the opening of the new noodle place Umani since I read about its conception. Having studied the history of ancient Japanese art culture in college has made me a bit of a Japanophile due to the subtle approach they take in all things beautiful; and Umami pulls this off.   My daughter and I went there for lunch and sat next to the blooming orchid in the  alcove near the entrance. (Good for a escape route with an almost 3-year old). We were greeted right away and made to feel welcome. We choose one of three lunch combination options. The Miso Udon with Roast Pork soup (other choices include chicken and shitake) and the Chicken and Shitake Dumplings for ten bucks (other choices are pork, chicken and chives & veggie). They were nice enough to bring us edamame that wasn't on the menu.   The Soup was out of sight. Although I wish it were hot I know that is sacrilege to a Miso which survives to be the most nourishing at a certain temperature. The noodles were perfect. The Pork melted in my mouth. I had to ask about the infused egg which was quite honestly,  a turn-on. An almost hard boiled chicken egg with a creamy center but not runny. It had a dark liquid running through it which the waiter couldn't explain to me.   Which brings me to the service. Of corse Umami is still working out the kinks of what a new restaurant brings and I understand that. So I can overlook the waiter not knowing how to describe something, especially when it's so damn good. But what's hard to comprehend is the counter service. In a day and age where people don't have money to tip but still want to dine out, a lot of counter service joints have sprung up. But Umami lends itself to table service. I don't want my dumplings or soup to get cold while I go up to order another Sake. And even more important, I might not order another Sake because I have to get up and leave my food and my experience!  The experience is lovely here. With wall accents of ripe and unripe persimmon colors and the slate grey bar with bamboo inspired tile. The place is simple and sophisticated with and great ambient music and discrete lighting. It's just so wonderful that I want someone to bring me my drink so that I can take it all in and not put it on pause. I dream of going back without a child to get a buzz that only good sake can give, and to try the Ahi tuna seaweed salad and the braised pork belly buns with homemade hoisin sauce.

Finally had a chance to stop by Umami's restaurant after having their delicious Bao's at the Farmer's Market. My overall experience was just average.   The Food   Our order consisted of a Brunch Ramen, and 2 Pork Belly Bun. I'd have to say the Brunch Ramen was something new, it consisted of bacon bits, egg, pork belly, and some sides such as cabbage, bamboo, and garlic. The broth was flavorful but just Luke-warm. Egg was cooked perfectly, not overcooked, still a bit runny just the way it should be. Pork belly wasn't the best, the fat to meat ratio was off; there was little to no fat It felt like I was eating a normal piece of pork. Bacon as a topping was new, I probably wouldn't get it again; it diluted the flavor of the broth and every bite tasted like bacon.   The Buns Same issue, Pork belly was not fatty enough. Although the Buns were perfect still a bit moist, soft, and still hot when served. I remember it tasting 2x better at the farmer's market.   Pricing   Everything was reasonably priced, Ramen was $10 a bowl and then the buns were $3 per.   Service   Server's were very attentive. We were greeted and seated right away, no complaints.  Decor   Restaurant is basically inside an apartment/house like many other restaurants on Williamson street. Very small and comforting atmosphere. They do also have a bar in the middle of the restaruant.   Parking   Small parking lot behind the restaurant, so there's no need to look for parking.   Overall  Pork Belly could have been better.  Baos were great  Ambiance is small and comforting  I'll probably give Umami another try during dinner hours.

I truly wanted to like this place :( I have been spoiled with amazing, good-to-the-last-slurp ramen in Los Angeles and I'm quite familiar with how ramen should taste. Umami sadly pales in comparison. I ordered the Miso chicken ramen which I was looking forward to as many ramen places only offer pork broth and meat. Unfortunately, the broth was bland and the noodles were overly cooked; the only redeeming ingredient was the flavor-infused egg. I also tried the Umami arugula salad which was quite fresh but the dressing on the salad ruined it (too bitter). I gave one extra star because the restaurant ambience is intimate and cute, and it was easy to get outdoor seating.

I'm glad they have a vegan ramen option here- but I was unimpressed, as was my boyfriend. Many authentic and delicious ramen noodles are vegan, so it would help if they would provide a vegan wheat noodle option instead of defaulting to the vegan and gluten-free rice noodle option. I love rice noodles, but it's not exactly what I want when I think ramen. The flavors of the broth were meh, too. My boyfriend has had non-vegan ramen there and said it was just ok.

Ugh. The service. Is it a joke? I want to give zero stars but can't, & I guess that's alright because the saketinis are great and the buns are good. (Although newsflash: the "spicy bomb" is a plate with a dollop of sriracha on it for an extra $1). The dumplings and ramen are decent but what does it matter when you're just sitting, with your menus, without even a glass of water for *20* minutes? The service (during restaurant week no less) is so bad that the last time we were there (I had been planning this for over a week; it was my birthday), my husband and I just got up and walked out. Once the hostess seated us she told us our server would explain the restaurant week menu to us shortly. So we waited. And waited. And waited. Because I really wanted a white ice saketini. But my husband and I decided that 20 minutes of being treated like we were invisible was just too damn long. What a bummer. It was our third and last time there. With each visit the service has been worse. And if your server is an older dude with a beard and a manbun? Run. You're not getting served unless it is by dancing youths. Grumble grumble grumble. What a disappointment.

Get either the miso soup or the dumplings!    You have never had real miso soup before if you think of the cloudy salty crap from a powder packet that's served in most Japanese restaurants.  Here, they make it for real and it's amazing!  For added fun, get a flavor infused egg!  The dumpling are rocking.  Hot and authentic, you couldn't ask for more.  Try all three sauces!

This is my favorite spot for brunch on the east side of Madison.  The patio is lovely, nicely shaded.  Sweet lord, the dumplings... Edamame dumpling with spicy sauce (exquisite), the classic pork and chive (oh so good).  Try the spicy tofu buns - pillowy light goodness with fried tofu, pickled cucumbers, spicy scallion salsa and mayo. I always get the Brunch ramen -- with a spicy bomb and garlic bomb.  Hearty flavorful vegan broth is amazing.  A flavor infused egg is heavenly.  Great service, chill vibe, and enough ramen to take home and enjoy the next day (I add a soft fried egg).  Don't forget a ginger peach rum fizz -- a refreshing breakfast beverage for this lady.  The Vietnamese-style iced coffee is also mighty fine.  Go.

Now that there are two ramen places in Madison, I feel it's imperative that the two be compared. This review hopes to answer any questions you might have in deciding whether to go here, Umami, or its competition, Ramen Kid. To test consistently, I ordered a classical Japanese ramen meal - pan-fried pork gyoza and tonkatsu ramen - at both places.   First thing, Umami is pretty. I love the decor, and the bar is really nice. In fact, a lot of people were there for drinks instead of food. But when it comes to food, I am relatively unimpressed with it. Their gyoza was done well, better than at Ramen Kid. The skin was perfectly crisp, and I loved the sauce that came with it (I got the sweet vinegar sauce). However, the ramen itself was not so great. I think they were going for an oilier ramen concept, because the pork slices were quite fatty (which did mean that they were quite tender) and the broth was really heavy. But it was not as properly savory as I would have liked, and not as savory as the ramen at Ramen Kid. Their ramen came with half of a soft-boiled egg, bamboo shoots, and nori. The restaurant also claims that they make their own noodles. That may be so, but that doesn't really excuse you from cooking your noodles through - there was a visible core of uncooked dough in each noodle, which made it taste doughy and chewy*. Finally, I distinctly noticed that there were temperature differences between the broth, pork slices, and bamboo shoots, which makes me suspect that they assembled the dish in a hurry and hadn't properly heated/let the ingredients sit together and equilibrate.  It seems that Umami does everything else besides ramen well, so you might want to come here if you're looking for, say, buns or a drink. Go to Ramen Kid if you want just ramen.  *NB: my Chinese grandmother taught me that you check when Asian noodles are cooked by looking at the ends. Take them out as soon as you can't see any opaque white dough, when the end looks just translucent. Whoever makes Umami's noodles, take note!

So as it turns out, Umami's beef buns are some of the best things to eat in the WHOLE WORLD! I very much believe that is not an exaggeration. Truly amazing beef buns - so amazing, in fact, that we requested a second order after just 3 bites (2 buns per order). Let me dig down to the delicious details for you.  The Korean BBQ beef used in the bun is incredibly tender with delightfully crispy edges and a wonderful, deep flavor. The spicy mayo has a nice, creamy heat, but not at all overpowering (I'm fairly sensitive to spice) because the thinly sliced cucumbers combined with a soft bun enveloping it all creates a lovely balancing effect. I will crave these buns until the next time I'm there, which I hope is very soon.  The edamame appetizer was exactly what we wanted - nice & warm topped with lots of course salt. And the pork & chive dumplings were also very good with a sweet, tangy dipping sauce. But the beef buns just stole the show, so there it is.  Brittany was our server and she was nothing, but helpful, fun and fabulous. You'll know her by her height, her blonde hair and her adorable dance moves. I was a first timer at Umami and she was full of great info and suggestions. She was attentive and yet knew when to let my friend and I just chat away. The last piece of goodness is that we were there for happy hour so our mixed drinks were 2 for 1. Hooray!  Now be good and go get some beef buns immediately!

Food: 5 Service: 4 Uniqueness: 4  ---------------------------------------------------------------- So I didn't know what to expect from a ramen joint in Madison Wisconsin but the steamed buns from their food cart by the campus were incredible. As a result my wife and I went to check it out and we're blown away. This place is on par with ramen in San Francisco or Seattle and is probably one of the best places in the midwest.  Definitely try the buns. The porkbelly buns are standard and tasty but the unique ones are the spicy beef buns with cucumber kimchi and spicy mayo. Those are delicious.   The tonkatsu ramen is outstanding! The broth is rich and flavorful and the noodles are perfect. The other ramen broths are ok. We've tried several of the others which are good but not nearly as noteworthy as the tonkatsu.

Great comforting food matched with pleasant service!  We went this past Saturday for a late lunch and boy was this placed packed to its gills! I guess it'd be wise to plan a 30-45 min wait in your schedule when planning this joint esp. in and around peak hours. Here's my thoughts on the food once we did finally get to eat!  Pork Belly Bun - Excellent! The bun was not to spongy nor was it dry. The pork belly was melt in your mouth cooked and the hoisin sauce paired really well with it. Must try!  Tonkotsu ramen - Delicious! The broth was creamy and had a "soothe your senses" sort of taste to it. The braised pork was cooked to perfection and really complimented the flavors of the broth. The noodles were light and portioning balanced. The add-ons of Garlic and Spicy bombs really elevated the dish and gave another dimension to it!   Green tea Creme Brulee - Sinful! The green tea wasn't bitter or overpowering the otherwise usually subtle flavor of a typical custard. In fact it was a very good play on flavors and ended up being the Star of our evening!! Highly recommended!

Ramen? In the morning? I'll admit it took me some time to come around to Umami as a brunch option. Friends have talked about how magnificent and unique of a place Umami is for brunch and I finally caved.  First, the Umami bloody mary. Goodness! It is a delicious take on the traditional bloody mary, and for the chance to try a quail egg it is totally worth the upgrade from the standard offering.   I opted away from ramen, and instead tried the Spicy Umami Burrito which I am still daydreaming about currently. The combination of spicy pulled pork, scallion pancake, and kimchi makes for quite the breakfast treat. It never hurts to add in some side dumplings or buns because why not!  Umami's portion sizing is very generous, and I find that I am always taking home leftovers whether it be from dinner or brunch. Can't recommend this place enough!

I. love. Umami. It's actually the first restaurant I ever went to in Madison, which really set a high standard for future dining ventures :) Whenever my boyfriend and I can't decide where to eat, we default to Umami. We usually order bottomless matcha tea (though I've tried a few of their cocktails and they're all delicious), the pork & chive dumplings, and the ramen special with a spicy bomb. They have an awesome option to split a ramen entree with extra protein (2 eggs, more pork belly) for just a couple dollars!  The service is always great, the ambiance is cozy, and while I haven't tried the patio yet I am DYING to do so.   Oh, aaand they have brunch on the weekends, which has literally changed my life. I want breakfast ramen and egg & bacon dumplings for every meal, not just every brunch.

Umami always delivers when I am hankering for some solid food.  My go to dishes are usually the pork burns along with the chicken and shrimp dumplings.  I feel the pork buns are some of the best in town.  The fattyness of the pork offset by the sliced cucumbers and hoisin sauce make it incredibly addicting.  This time, my girlfriend and I also went with the tuna poke.  Served with some variation of a chip, the tuna was fresh and evenly sauced with soy and sesame oil.  While I still feel the pork buns ruled the night, the poke was a nice change of pace.  Umami also is one of the few places that serves up Hitachino beer (little owl) so that is always a plus.

I love the dumplings here. The ramen is pretty damn good too. I can't say I like the building much. The staff are friendly and the location isn't bad. My biggest problem is the price. I know it's a higher class ramen, but I could still make it at home and don't want to pay so much. Which would be why I haven't been back.

Service was impeccable last night. I got the Vegan Dumplings. They were recommended by the person who seated us. Super tasty with their hot sauce!  I also ordered some of their Sake. Very good too. They always came by and refilled our waters, too. That was very nice.  Definitely coming back to this place

The atmosphere, as Melissa J mentioned, is stylish. The lights are fairly low and the noise level is relatively peaceful. It's a very nice and subdued place, which is probably what you'd expect of a more upscale Japanese restaurant lacking a hibachi grill.  I went for the grand opening tonight and I was only slightly disappointed: they have a fixed menu with some limited items. There's appetizers, salads, dumplings, ramen, and some desserts. However, there's only several listed for each type. The drinks list is also fairly limited, but if you're into beer and sake-type drinks, you'll be fairly pleased. There are some alternative beverages, but don't expect a lot of soda, wines, or other types outside of this.  I got myself a glass of the Chardonnay and the tonkotsu ramen. The Chardonnay was a terrible mistake on my end of things: it doesn't seemingly pair well with anything on the menu, so it was a poor decision, in retrospect. Not their fault on this one.  The tonkotsu ramen was good, but not great. It was very mild and soft, but lacked a special flavor. The noodles were good and the char siu pork was incredible. I'd wished they'd put some more in because it'd certainly add some more flavor to the broth.  The service was a little spotty, too: it took us a few minutes to be noticed by a staff member who just told us to sit at a bar. Then, when we did, it took about 15 minutes for us to be asked about ordering anything. I understand it was the first night and some things were probably getting worked out, though.  Overall, it was a great atmosphere and decent food. A little expensive, but not the worst. I'd come back.

Came here on a Saturday just before the big lunch rush and wasn't disappointed. I was impressed with the extensive menu options despite the fact that Wisconsin may not be known for its ramen shops! All of the waitstaff was extremely pleasant and it seemed like a very "hipster" place. Service got a little slow near the lunchtime rush but that wasn't their faults. I was impressed with the vegan, vegetarian, and regular options. Started off with the Thai milk tea. I wasn't a huge fan of it because it seemed overall too creamy without a strong flavor at all.   Next we had the bacon omurice and the brunch ramen. I think part of my 5 star review is that you can't go wrong with bacon. The omurice was very simple in itself. It was nice egg surrounding some rice that consisted of just rice and bacon - very simple but hearty because bacon and bacon fat is delicious.   The brunch ramen was great! I've heard complaints of it being too thin because the brunch broth base does not have any pork, but it was surprisingly savory and perfect for lunch. There was also bacon in it, but the standouts were the bamboo, egg, and pork belly. The pork belly was very very tender and the ramen consisted of all my favorite toppings. The ramen was came out to be a little pricey (there have been better for less - but it's a great little spot in Madison!

We went for brunch on Sunday at 10 am and started out with the beef steam buns. They were exceptional. I mean I eat food and it tastes good. I also had the bacon dumplings that were just amazing with expert construction and cookery; and the filling was just gooey bacony excellence. The atmosphere was...I don't know because my face was in my food, I could have been siting in blizzard hurricane lightning radioactive apocalypse and I wouldn't have noticed. Also get the spicy mayo with the dumplings, I wanted to swim in it.   Babe got three sides, the rosemary potatoes, eggs over easy, and regular bacon all made perfectly. Service was excellent. I want to go back right now, but I am at work far away from this delicious food...oh the insanity!!!!

Willy Street delivers again! Umami is that rare experience in Madison that provides an alternative to your usual place. Ramen is given new meaning, and did I mention the pork dumplings? Don't order 6, opt for 9, you'll thank me later. Great, attentive service, excellent, authentic noodles, dumplings, and rolls, Umami is my new go to location on Willy Street.

Went with my daughter on a brisk spring evening.  The atmosphere is both hip and comfortable.  We sat at the bar and began with a perfect martini.  The pork and chive dumplings were outstanding-everything you want from dumplings but seldom find.  They were succulent, light, and flavorful.  I had the tonkotsu ramen and added pork belly and the spicy bomb.  The broth was good and the pork and especially the pork belly was tasty.  The spicy bomb would have benefitted by a more complex mixture of flavors.  My daughter had the miso ramen with chicken.  She felt that it was a bit bland.  We both thought that a runny, rather than hard-boiled, egg would have enhanced the flavors and textures. Service was efficient and friendly.  All told, it was a pleasant and very affordable evening out and perfect for a cold spring day.

Small but good menu. If you like Ramen noodles this is the spot. I like their buns, great style fold over buns with scrumptious fillings. Dumplings also cooked nice with great selection of siblings. My always favorite is the Poker, this is an app size. Good for two. Service prompt , beer bar  cocktail selections awesome.

Always enjoy going to Umami! Try the pork buns and dumplings to start.. or just get a bunch to share along with some cocktails and call it a night! The patio is a lovely place to sit outside on Willy St. and the casual atmosphere is always relaxing. Definitely worth checking out.

our experience was pretty spot-on with the rest of the reviews here.  the pork buns were amazing and the chicken shitaki dumplings were great.  i ordered one of the fruity cocktails and it rocked.  this place would easily be five stars if you just showed up for a cocktail and appetizers.  the ramen, on the other hand, was so incredibly disappointing.  i ordered the vegetable ramen with a garlic bomb and topped with corn.  the noodles were amazing but the broth was so salty that the meal was actually inedible.  it was a deep msg tasting salt that actually hurt my throat to swallow the broth.  so depressing because i LOVE ramen and wanted to write a glowing review.  the folks behind the bar were very friendly when we walked in and we were seated right away for an early friday night dinner.  our waiter was very nice but not very quick on the ball about attending to our needs.  the apps came out in a short amount of time but the ramen took close to 35 minutes - and it was literally us and maybe five other tables at that point.  we know they're not hand-making the noodles and ramen broth (good ramen broth) is a perpetual process...  we found that confusing.  and i'm HAPPY to wait 35 minutes for amazing ramen.  clearly not so happy to wait for inedible salt hell.  i'd go back for the tuna poke and those pork dumplings... damn.  so so good in an otherwise not so great restaurant.

LOVED IT!  We started with the spicy tofu buns and the chicken and shiitake dumplings which were both amazing.  Love the flavors of the pickling and the delicious sauces to dip these in....mmmmmm.  I had the shoyu ramen with a spice bomb, one word "delicious!" We also happened to be there for happy hour which was a bonus as it was 2 for 1 rail and tap.  I will definitely be going back as I am already craving the spicy tofu buns!

Tip: parking behind the house. Didn't know that for my first trip and I parked on the street.   I got the Omurice for brunch with a friend and they got ramen. I really liked the idea of the Omurice but I would say it was very salty because of the bacon. It would have been nice if it was pork belly or just less bacon. The bacon was in large chunks too.  I highly recommend the potstickers with eggs, bacon and chives. This was absolutely delicious. I'm definitely ordering this again.   The service was ok. Our water was refilled just once but my friend ever got a refill on their coffee.  Space. It's intimate. Cute for a date night. Probably not the best for large groups (no more than 8). I am sure it's packed for dinner. Brunch was not so busy at opening time. You can make a reservation via email for brunch. Not sure if this is necessary but do it anyways?   I'll probably go again and this one try their ramen. There are a lot options on their menu. I can't wait to explore some more.

This place is really awesome! We came here twice within a couple weeks because it was so good. We came here for brunch and the Ramen was delicious. We also had a burrito as well as the omurice. Every entree we had here was amazing! Definitely worth a try

If I lived on the Eastside, I would probably go broke eating here. Steamed buns, dumplings, and Ramen are all my favorite things to eat and Umami does them all right. I have such a hard time ordering when I go here since everything I have ever tried has been amazing. Dang, now I want to go to Umami now for lunch. If you are reading this still, stop, and just go get yourself some steamed buns from Umami now.

This is one of Madison's best noodle joints. The buns are always good... It's a toss up between the pork or beef buns. In the dumplings, I prefer the pork dumplings over the other varieties.   I think I've sampled most of the Raman - But prefer something with pork in it. The salads are also nice, but given the near zero temp, it was definitely a noodle night. We split the special - of course it had a nice slab of pork belly as one of the protein components.   We also had an order of the spicy beef buns and an order of the pork dumplings. The bill was $30... Not bad for two.

Awesome food! Would be 5 stars if the waitstaff cared. Again Awesome food.   Appetizers came out (we ordered when we were seated) and then we waited about 10 minutes to place our dinner order. They came out at the same time.   Server took over 20 minutes to check on how food was. We asked another server to refill our waters and bring 2 of us forks. She said sure but never returned. We were in no hurry but a 1 hour dinner took almost 2 1/2 hours because the servers seemed to forget us.  but remember the food was AWESOME!

Really enjoyed this place. Its a small location, was a home at one point and parking can be tricky. We got lucky with one of the few spots in back. The place is small so does not hold a ton of people. The menu is not loaded with options, mostly appetizers, dumplings and variation of ramen. But everything was super good and for sure made right on sight. We started with the tuna poke that some of the best I have ever had, then some of the little pork bun sandwiches which were great and the platter of pickled vegetables. I had the house special pork ramen with some extra eggs in it. Super good broth. No too rich or fatty. Good house made noodles also. Our party of five loved everything we had. Service was great. Would for sure go here again.,

I'm so glad we stumbled upon this gem. Located in an old house turned into a restaurant this place has lots to offer. We came for lunch on Sunday. It was pretty crowded but the staff was nice and we ended up not waiting too long at all.  I started off with a guava mimosa! Just based on that alone I would be back. Yumm! They had regular mimosas as well as mango and peach ones. The Bloody Mary was intriguing as well with a quail egg but we passed on this Sunday.  Our waitress was nice and quick to take our order and refill waters. She even made us kid friendly chopsticks for the 8yr old in the group.  We started with the beef buns which were very good. I want to try the spicy tofu ones next time. For entrees I had the tofu kimchi hash and my boyfriend got the brunch ramen. Both things were very good and cooked perfectly. There are also dumplings on the menu which look amazing and veggie and began ramen as well. I was very impressed by how many vegetarian and vegan options they had on the menu. I will definitely be back with my veggie loving friends to try them out! Can't wait to try dinner and their other cocktails!

Four of us recently had a very lovely Saturday brunch at Umami. The buns are as delicious as always, and the vegetarian options are extensive. My pescatarian friend was overwhelmed by how many choices she had.   Kudos to Umami!

I ordered the tonkatsu ramen. The broth was milky and relatively flavorful. It was a bit on the salty side. The pork was pretty tender and the egg was cooked just right with the yolk being a little runny. I was a little disappointed with the noodles. They weren't very eggy, chewy, and al dente.   For Madison, I would give the place 3 stars. It can't compare to NYC or California.

In all honesty I was trying to find something to make it so I didn't give this place a five star rating because I give every place a five star rating. But I could not find a single reason!  Everything about this place is wonderful. The staff is very good. From giving great recommendations, to coming to the table often but not too much.  It is also nice that they have so many options for vegetarians and vegans. It is surprisingly hard to find a lot of vegetarian options in a city with so many restaurants. It is nice to have vegetarian options that don't end at salad.  Their collection of cocktails is also wonderful. Every one that I have tried so far is delicious. Light and refreshing with enough flavor that it doesn't taste like I'm drinking straight rubbing alcohol.  If there was anything I would take away a star for, it would be that they aren't open long enough!  I can't wait to try their brunch sometime because I have heard amazing things.

When I see a sub-4 star overall rating on yelp I have certain expectations and I'll often actually avoid the place. But a friend of mine wanted to check Umami out so I checked my assumptions. And I loved it! We went during restaurant week so it was packed at we ate at the bar. The buzz in the place was great and you could tell it was a place where people were having a great time.  Brandon and I ignored the restaurant week menu (simply because it would have been WAY too much food) and we shared an order of the buns, the dumplings, and we split a bowl of ramen. The pork belly buns were delicious. The pork was soft and flavorful and the hoisin sauce was the perfect pair.The dumplings were less remarkable simply because they bore a strong resemblance to Asian Kitchen take out, but I love Asian Kitchen take out, so I thought they were good. The tonkotsu ramen was delicious. This was the part I was most nervous about because people seemed to have the most negative opinions about that. But it was great. The broth was flavorful, the noodles were nice and thin. The egg was absolutely delicious. Even the pork, which was my least favorite part, was nice and salty and added a lot of flavor. On a tip from another yelper, we decided to split a bowl. It's $1.50 extra and they give you separate bowls, extra meat, and an extra egg. Great deal and the perfect amount of food.

My boyfriend and I gave Umami a try after discussing getting soup. We usually go to Ha Long Bay, which is not a comparison as they are different meals entirely, but we were hoping to expand our soup expertise.  It's weird walking into a house, but the space inside is really quite nice. We were sat in a three table corner, which was a little snug and seemed too close at first, but was actually pretty cozy once seated.  The atmosphere I would give more stars to. It is really quite surprising how nice it is inside and they did a good job utilizing the space.  Staff wise they were very friendly. Our waters were never empty and our waitress, DeAnna, was really friendly.   We started with the pork chive dumplings, which were good. We got the sweet sauce, which had a nice flavor. They were hot, but not too hot, and easy to eat. Cooked very well, but like other reviews say, they were simply just that: dumplings.  Now for the Ramen. I know that it includes Rp pasta, but $11 was way too much for this size bowl. The soup came out, I had the veggie and my boyfriend had the tonkatsu, and it wasn't piping hot. Just a little more than warm. The presentation was nice, but once we dived in we found ourselves pretty underwhelmed. I enjoyed it a first, but the shiitake flavor both in the broth and in the whole mushrooms became very overwhelming about half way. My boyfriend, champ of soups, found the noodles to be a little lack luster but said that the egg in the soup was perfect. The egg was the best part.  I tried veggie because I'm not a huge fan of pork or chicken, but it seemed that maybe the veggie dish required more of a chicken broth to balance out the shiitake mushrooms.  I didn't finish my soup, but was offered a box which was nice. I don't think we will return for soup, but maybe for a drink and an appetizer. We will stick with our Thai noodle soups and continue on out soup journey.  Staff A+ / Space B / Food C-

We ordered the following for takeout:  1 order of pork buns: I've had these at their cart before, and they are just as tasty at the restaurant. This was the highlight.   2 seaweed salads:  Nicely dressed with some lightly pickled (I think) mushrooms  2 large orders of dumplings (18 total) - classic pork and chive and pork/shrimp combo:  Thoroughly mediocre.  Greasy, overcooked, and slightly dry. It doesn't seem like they serve steamed dumplings, which is a pity. They're not bad, but they're not particularly good either.   The whole thing came to $38. That's too much for a moderate spread of appetizers. I doubt we'll be back anytime soon.

PAT-I-O! This is one of my favorite outdoor dining spots in Madison. Come on people, we live in Wisconsin, we gotta soak up those rays and warmth while we can!  While we're talking about spring, try the spring rolls. They're super fresh and the peanut/spicy sauces are divine.    Annnnd obligatory dumpling mention. I could eat the vegan dumplings every day for the rest of my life and not get bored, but instead fall progressively deeper and deeper in love with them.
the broth was really salty but most ramen places are. Just a regular bowl but then again, coming from Southern California, I've got high standards.

My boyfriend and I tried this place together on a Friday evening without a reservation. It seemed like we were lucky to find a parking spot in the small lot and upon entering we were surprisingly seated immediately. We ordered the pork buns to share and our own bowls of pork ramen. The pork buns were decent; a little chewy and room temperature. (I thought they were supposed to be hot?) But the ramen was simply delicious and came in a very large portion. My boyfriend completely devoured all of his ramen and I finished as much as I could of mine. The ambience of the small restaurant was cozy but very welcoming and enjoyable. My boyfriend and I were able to enjoy a delectable meal; with the help of our fantastic server who answered all of our questions as first-time visitors and offered his own personal favorites on the menu. Will definitely be back!

PROS: Tasty, decent portions and prices CONS: ?  Rather than serving authentic Japanese ramen, Umami leans toward fusion flavors. My piping hot Veggie Brunch Ramen hit the spot. The soy milk in the dashi broth added a new, unexpected dimension to the usual miso-based vegetarian broth. One of these wintry days, I would love to drop by again to explore more items off the menu. For example... dumplings!

The word "ramen" usually conjures up 10 cent instant noodle packs you can buy at the gas station; the main food staple for many college students. However, ramen at Umami is anything but that. My boyfriend and I split a bowl of tonkotsu ramen and a small order of pork and chive dumplings. The dumplings were good, but nothing to write home about. The ramen was pretty good, although the broth was a little on the salty side. I was skeptical about the flavored egg at first because I hate eggs, but I tried some anyway and it was pretty good. The seaweed and braised pork rounded out the flavors in the ramen. Overall, I would recommend Umami for their ramen.

This place has really gone down hill, I use to love coming here, it had great service, quality food and a wonderful ambiance. The food quality has significantly gone down hill. Both mine and my brothers ramen was missing our pork and we had almost no broth at all. We asked for more and they said they were all out... which is hard to believe at a place that specializes in ramen. I'm sad to say I was underwhelm with the food I use to love coming here. Needless to say I won't be going back.

Delicious pork dumplings and pork buns were solid too.  Great atmosphere, really hope this place does well.  Their service was a bit spotty--I'm still waiting for that booster seat the host told me he's bring me for my little son.  The food was great, so I'll look past it.

This is some decent ramen, but for the price I definitely prefer some of Madison's other offerings. The tonkatsu ramen is alright, but not amazing. The broth is too salty and garlicky for my taste, and very concentrated, which can get pretty overwhelming very quickly. I added pork belly and shiitake mushrooms, both of which were delicious, and I love the bamboo shoots, which have a wonderful texture and taste, but the pork it comes from was over cooked, dry, and tough. The noodles were nothing special.   The buns are my favorite things here, I love how soft and fluffy they are, and the shiitake and pork dumplings are also very good. If that's what you're looking for, it's a decent place to go, but there is better ramen for cheaper kn the area.

First time eating ramen and it won't be my last. It was the perfect meal for an extremely cold day in Madison. The beef buns were off the chain! The beef was seasoned perfectly. It was a just a tad bit dry however. Whatever dough they use for the buns would put pillsbury to shame! Take the dough boy!   I had the miso ramen which came with chicken and extra noodles. Loved the infused egg and flavor. My only complaint was the broth. I am not sure if this is something of ramen but it was murky and thick. Preferably, my broth is light almost like a tea consistency.   Overall, great dish, fantastic service and cozy atmosphere.

Completely disappointing. I had my doubts when we had trouble finding the place at night because the only sign they have is wooden with an inscription of a bowl in it.  Then we get inside. It looks pretty nice, that kind of urban hipster looking with a bar that seems pretty popular these days. Being the decisive people we are we order with relatively alacrity and then proceed to wait close to 20 minutes for our appetizer and then another 20 minutes for our entree. This is completely unacceptable, how long can it take to prepare a bowl of ramen?  As for the taste, the pork belly appetizer was pretty good though I found it kind of skimpy on the pork and really, how do you mess up pork belly?  Our bowls of ramen on the other hand were atrocious; muddy looking broth, a little too salty and basically no other flavor except a bitter aftertaste.  The pieces of meat were equally flavorless and boring.  The service however was good and when we complained the manager came out to get our opinions. Frankly, the food was beyond redemption, no amount of critiquing was going to allow the chef that prepared that ramen to cook something delicious.

Excellent Dinner and a pretty reasonable price. Mom and I  had the seaweed salad, chicken dumplings and split the miso ramen.  All the food was wonderful!  The seaweed salad was a wonderful surprise -  light, delicious and flavorful.  The ramen was also excellent - wonderful broth,  the meat was succulent and the noodles were firm and tender.

We had dinner here last night and had a blast!!! The location is small and actually located in a house, but has seating inside and outside on a deck.  The parking is in the back with about 5-6 spots available for cars.  We arrived with out a reservation, but were seated almost immediately on a Sunday night during Restaurant Week.  They had a great selection of cocktails, local beers, and significant wine list.   We ordered a few appetizers.  The fried tofu dish was ok...kind of smooshy in a soy sauce...didn't really care for it.  The seaweed salad was excellent, with marinated seaweed over shiitake mushrooms.  The spring roll was also well put together with dipping sauces.   We absolutely loved the Veggie and Spicy Veggie buns.  The buns were perfectly cooked with an incredible sauce on the inside that almost makes my mouth water thinking about it.  The spicy wasn't really all that spicy, but taste SOOOOO good.  The combination of the soft bread, cucumbers, and fried tofu...amazing.  The veggie dumplings were also well done with the crispy crust and  chewy top.  Also filled with a nice assortment of diced vegs and tofu.  The Veggie Ramen was good.  I am not a huge fan of Ramen, but the addition of the spice bomb, and garlic bomb was excellent.  The smoked tofu and noodles were cooked well, and the soup surrounding it was flavorful.  We also tried the mango ice cream Mochi which was o.k.  Overall this is a great noodle shop in Madison.  What I really loved was the attentive service.  Our waiter was getting killed with it being restaurant week and the place being packed, but he NEVER let our water glasses get empty.  He brought the food out in a perfectly timed method that allowed us to enjoy each dish.  Just plain excellent service.

The ramen was nothing to write home about--that being said, the pork belly buns and bulgogi buns we ordered as our appetizer were AMAZING. I'm talking melt-in-your-mouth-oh-my-god-do-i-want-twenty-more amazing! They were marinated to perfection and the meat was tender. Minus 1 star only because of the "meh" ramen and sticky tables.  (+) Pork belly & bulgogi buns A MUST (+) Small yet cozy with outdoor seating  (-) Sticky tables (-) Ramen was just ok

Way too salty. Despite that, the Ramen was not bad, but really good places have a more refined broth that relies less on salt for taste. Paying 50 ¬¢ for a dollop of hot sauce (their "Spice Bomb") that is free at most places was kind of a turn off. However it was a nice place with a cozy, nice ambience and great server.

Need to update after having better experiences. In particular, Umami offers an awesome restaurant week special.  Even my favorite restaurants tend to disappoint me during restaurant week. The portions are small, not nearly as good as usual and often aren't what the restaurant usually serves. They're dishes designed to be made in bulk, and probably cost less to make. Umami's restaurant week is superior in that they serve the most popular dishes on the menu, unchanged, for a great price - at $25, it's amongst the cheaper restaurant week meals.  The buns are phenomenal. I got the Korean beef and ate it in about two bites. The pork dumplings were very good and the Tonkotsu ramen was amazing. I don't remember it being so good! Definitely worth purchasing a spicy bomb. Enough food in there for two meals.  Took awhile to seat us but both the hostess and our waitress were friendly and smiled. Glad to see the improvement!

I order Ramen Noodle with Chashu Pork.  It was cold and in December, you had to get soupy something to stay warm.  The food was really delicious, the food came out quickly.  The customers sitting at the bar alongside me were very friendly.  The prices were reasonable.  Large Portions.  If you're visiting Wisconsin Dells, Wi, get your food here before you go because there is no good asian place in Wisconsin Dells.  It's an hour to wisconsin dell.  The food was really good.

Nice patio to enjoy the warm day in Madison. Yummy Ramen with Pork Buns with Thai Iced tea. The vegetarian Ramen The broth tasted authentic but I was expecting a variety of veggies in the soup. I'm just spoiled from the Seattle Ramen restaurants. I'll come back for another bowl and ask for extra veggies.  t-shirts were cool.. I'll buy 2 for my girls.

I really like Umami. I love the pork buns, the pork belly brightened by the tangy sauce, and the freshness of the scallions and pickles cucumbers nicely counters the fat. It's really the perfect combination in a single bite.   As for the ramen, I always get the tonkotsu, and I really really love the way they do their meat. I love pork fat. The broth is super rich and creamy without being weighted down, the eggs are always cooked perfectly rare and the bamboo slices are nicely marinated. I strongly feel that they are levels above other ramen establishments in town in terms of understanding the ingredients and execution. That said, the broth is a bit too salty for my taste, to the point that it leaves a slight bitter after taste. I wish they can hold back on the salt a little so it doesn't distract from all the other wonderful things in the bowl. Comparing to their competitions, though, they are outstanding.   Umami will continue to be my family's asian restaurant of choice.
Good food. Good value. Really good service. The menu is really cool - it is super eclectic and you will find something unexpected. I highly recommend this place.

Really good pork belly buns. The best tonkatsu ramen you will get in Wisconsin. Nothin compared to all the real authentic and delicious tonkatsu ramens in other cities, but when desperation hits, this does it. There's a small parking lot in the back and ambience is small and cute. Outdoor seating is really popular

I fell in love with the Umami Buns food cart and was SUPER EXCITED (more so than I probably should have been) to find out there was a brick-and-mortar restaurant, too! I was already in love with ramen cuisine and I enjoyed exploring Umami's menu! The Pear Blossom sake-tini is wonderful for drinks and I had the pork dumplings, edamame, and miso ramen. Very cute interior, too :)

This place is a completely solid 3.5 stars, but I'm going to round up because it has a small parking lot! It's pretty hard to find parking there (I guess only 6-7 cars could fit there), but it's better than nothing.   The ramen here is relatively good, the dumplings are relatively good, but nothing spectacular. I'm very confused when I see reviews about this being the best ramen they've had - it's certainly nothing special, but it will satisfy your ramen/dumpling craving!  It's honestly quite a small establishment, I was surprised! It's probably not good if you have a group of 5 or more...but you CAN make reservations for a group of 5 or more which is pretty cool! I would say that this place is pretty great for a date night.   The service was fine, relatively fast at getting the food out and refilling drinks, but otherwise it's just another ramen place.

UpDate!  The service was WAY quicker this time around! And our waiter recognized us (it's only our 2nd time and at least 3 wks in between) - I liked the greeting.   I ordered o-Cha (honey tea + Maker's Mark + mint leaf) deserves thumbs up. My bf and I shared bunch of appetizers and gyoza and skipped ramen. Everything tasted good! I loved the variation on veggie pickles. This time, the pickle plate included un-riped mango, jicama, and beets etc etc, which were all crunchy-delish.  With 5 plates and a drink, our dinner tab was ~ $40. Not bad at all :)
Fabulous setting (with parking) and great food.  I had the special dumplings (pur√©ed edamame) and the summer roll.  Dinner for $13 and it was a spectacular flavor bomb.

The food and service was really good. I agree with some of the other reviews which say that the ramen doesn't really compare with ramen places in other parts of the world (I haven't been to Japan but I have been to a few pretty authentic places in NYC and Hawaii). That being said, it's still a great meal. I didn't try the pork buns, but that's definitely on my list when I go back (emphasis on the *when*).

I love this restaurant for its Ramen and how quaint and cute the inside/outside is. From the appearance it is pretty safe that at one point it was a house that has been converted into a restaurant. As so the ambiance is very intimate, at most there is a table or two you can see and hear.   The menu features mainly buns, dumplings and ramen. There is also appetizers and some salads but everyone comes here for the ramen. My favorites on the menu are the spicy tofu buns and Miso Ramen. The tofu in the buns is crispy on the outside and cooked to perfection with slaw and a spicy mayo. All this is wrapped in the perfect fluffy bun.   The Miso Ramen is a miso base with chicken stock, chicken, noodles, flavor infused egg, bamboo shoots,and lots of great flavor. You can also add extras such as a spicy bomb(as usually get this), garlic bomb, extra meat, extra egg, etc. This is nice as you can make the dish very unique if you want. The ramen itself is rich and complex in flavor. It is the perfect thing on a cold rainy day. The only thing I do not like is it can be very salty but that comes with the territory.   Another thing to add is there saketini's are awesome. If you are a Sake fan I would highly recommend trying one.  Overall if you are looking for a restaurant that is different than your usual Wisconsin stop this is absolutely a must try. Once you try it you will become one of there many regulars.

Cool hip little place with interesting wall paintings (think murals of people swimming in bowls of ramen) and creative brunch offerings.  Perfect place to eat for brunch the next morning  after a late night - hits the spot!! The brunch menu is really creative and a bit asian fusion-y. They also have your standard waffles for the less adventurous (or pure breakfast souls) :) The portions are sizeable which is great!  They have 3 things essentially thay they're known for- the ramen, dumplings,  and the pork buns. Only had ramen and buns which were both awesome- so I recommend getting pork buns on the side and ramen as a main. You will be very full and satisfied.   The pork buns are good-- could maybe benefit from a little more sauce and green onion filling but overall really juicy pork belly and soft fluffy buns.   The ramen was really delicious-- especially the broth. Was not overly salty and was very flavorful. The noodles were perfectly Al dente and the variety of veggies was great.  So yummmmm!!!  Would most definitely go back and would probably be a regular if I lived here!
white people sure love this place.  buns = ehhh dumplings = why not cocktails = no way ramen = aye caramba blergh
HOLY YUM!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  just Yaaassssss!  LOVE the Ramen so much had the pork one.... OMG I just cant even describe! MUST TRY

I really enjoyed the veggie ramen! it was delicious and it came it quickly. My server Leah was very attentive and one of the nicest servers I have ever had. I recommend this place and getting Leah as server. I will be going back for sure :)

Cozy ramen bar serving limited but perfectly nice menu of ramen, dumplings and pork buns. There is a children's menu with nice selections, but if you think you are going to get chicken fingers and pizza, go elsewhere. Our well-behaved seven-year-old was perfectly fine here. Decor was spare and certainly kept some of the spirit of the original house.

Went here last night and I'm pretty sure I got food poisoning from the pork in the ramen. I went home and two hours later I felt nauseous and vomited. Food was mediocre, and the broth was lukewarm which was probably why the pork was undercooked

Points for being a rehabbed home, but that's where most of the excitement stops. Staff has never been all to welcoming/friendly/warm/suggestion-oriented and honestly up and down Willy I can get some pretty mean dumplings at a number of places. Their buns are tasty though, I'll give them that, but I just don't think it's worth the trip for one specialty item.
This restaurant has been a staple of my diet for years.  I recommended this restaurant years ago, and I would still again.   Order the Tonkotsu ramen and the pork belly buns.

Grabbed dinner and drinks here to round out a weekend visiting Madison. There was a little bit of a wait as their kitchen was apparently under-staffed for the day but nothing that was unreasonable.   The restaurant itself has a nice and homey feel and the wait-staff was super friendly!  We ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with extra noodles and a spicey bomb and the Pork and Chives dumplings. The Ramen was delicious!! The noodles were perfectly cooked and with the spice bomb the broth was the perfect level of spicy! The egg was also perfectly cooked in the ramen which is always a nice surprise. The dumplings were also quite tasty and the spicy dipping sauce it comes with hit the spot!   We rounded out the night with a few mango mojitos which were a perfect refresher on a hot night!   Overall I was a huge fan of this place! The Ramen was spot on!

Finally tried Umami last night after walking past it a thousand times. Great decor and atmosphere - cool bar area appears to be an addition on the back of a house that has been converted into seating space for the restaurant. The interior was clean and hip and unexpected based on impression from the outside.  Menu was fairly small and to the point: comprised of starters, "buns", dumplings, and ramen. Hubby and I were starving and ordered spicy pulled pork buns to start with. They came out within 3-4 minutes and were very tasty.   We opted to share a large order of dumplings (pork and scallion?) and a bowl of ramen. Dumplings were good - took a long time to come out. Our server had warned us of the delay - about 15 minutes she said. They actually took closer to 25-30. Came out VERY hot (Seriously, be careful!)  and were pretty good. Nothing wrong with them, I just expected them to be... better. We had just had VERY GOOD dumplings at Ha Long Bay the week before, so I may have been biased.   The Tonkotsu Ramen was served in a big bowl - enough for us to share, although a bit awkward to each be slurping noodles out of the bowl in the middle of the table. Great warming and filling broth, pork, bamboo shoots, a soft boiled egg.  We didn't add any "toppings" to the ramen, but I was intrigued by the garlic bomb and would probably get that next time.   Overall, we left happy and with full bellies for a decent price. I'll probably return for my very own bowl of ramen.

I'm local to Madison and have tried many restaurants in the area. Umami remains one of my favorite restaurants. The buns are incredible - very soft and filled with tangy spice. The ramen is FRESH and that makes all the difference in terms of taste. Umami's cozy location offers the excitement of dining out as well as the comfort of a home.

This gem was on my list for some time now. Stopped in with my girl on a Tuesday night. (Last night) once we walked in, there was a small line.  However we were seated quite quickly. Still could not believe how packed for a Tuesday night!  I like old houses revamped and zoned for restaurants. Decor was nice and simple. Waiter was very kind and helpful. Beef Bun apps were Freaken amazing!! The Ramen noodles were definitely home made. My mother makes home made for her chicken soup. Ramen Noodles were not as starchy.  In short, the Miso Ramen with added pork was fantastic!!  Can't wait to go again!!

We stopped in here on Saturday night and were surprised to see it wasn't more busy.  It's unassuming from the outside (it's in an old house), but the decor inside is very cool and lounge-y.  We ordered saki-tinis, pork dumplings, and veggie and miso ramen.  Drinks were interesting and fruity without being too sweet--you could definitely take the sake.  Dumplings were delicious and we'd recommend the spicy dipping sauce.  Both our ramen bowls were excellent, not at all too salty (as other reviewers suggested), and I'm pretty sensitive to overly salty foods.  Overall, great value for the price, since the ramen bowls are huge and only $10 each.  Good variety on the menu, and love that they're open late and serving the full menu until midnight on weekends.  Service was very attentive and the server was knowledgable and able to recommend dishes.  (Definitely beats Natt Spill!)

I was pretty underwhelmed by Umami.   Yes, they serve dumplings. They're no better or worse than dumplings I've eaten at a Chinese restaurant, or even those that I've bought that were made fresh with the sushi at the grocery store. The pork buns were not bad, but again, nothing spectacular. A little overpriced for what you get. Good specialty cocktails but nothing super amazing. Some friends ordered other dishes and everyone was pleased, but not ecstatic.   Been there, done that, probably won't return.

We had a wonderful time tonight at Umami during Restaurant Week! We've never been here before, but I hope we'll go again many more times.  I should mention that usually I hate Chinese steamed buns ... mostly because I think the texture is odd, and the ones I've had before were filled with weird tastes that were new, but unappealing. NOT HERE. I was sad I only got to have one bun as part of the Restaurant Week menu, but never fear, there's a food cart right by my job!  I got the spicy tofu bun and loved it. It was not spicy enough/as spicy as I was expecting, but it was still tasty. Then I got the vegan dumplings -- excellent as well, but they kept falling apart. Then, a veggie ramen bowl. It was a perfect summer night, and a little chilly, so the ramen was also perfect. It got pretty heavy and salty for me by the end but I loved all the veggie flavors and noodles. I also love the noodles are made by R.P.'s ! Lastly, I tried the black sesame mochi. No complaints here!  Our waitress was nice, location was great, etc. Thanks Umami!
I told that chef that if I knew the date of my death, that I would want him to create my last meal. He is a genius.

This past year I have seen ramen restaurants on the travel channel.  I have said to Rhonda, "Why doesn't Madison have ramen".  I wasn't looking hard enough.  Umami is here and it is really good.  Restaurants in Chicago, LA and NY should have better food but I am very proud of the restaurant scene in Madison.  Umami doesn't disappoint.  For it's location, parking is plentiful.  The decor is great.  I was a little worried at first about how our service was going to be but it turned out to be great.  We arrived when they opened and all the staff was standing around talking.  Being that they are all young and the restaurant is trendy I thought we would be treated bad but I was wrong.  Our server was funny and the bartender knew her job well.  Rhonda had a mojito and I even liked it.  We had the dumplings.  WOW, I thought I have had some good dumplings in the past but I didn't know.  Umami's were great.  The only bad thing I can say about the ramen is I thought it would have been a little spicier.  Next time we go back I am going to ask about it.  The flavors were delicate and very fresh.  You could taste each ingredient.  We will be going back.

Food is phenomenal, but the service is laughably bad. It almost seems like a schtick. When I asked the waiter if I could sit with my wife for 10 minutes while she waited for her friend for dinner on a patio with roughly 6 other open tables, I was told doing so is against their "seating policy." I even ordered a drink. Hard to believe a place that has a "seasonal" dish that is easily the best thing on the menu and could undoubtedly be offered year round has a policy for anything, but okay.   Don't waste your time. There are too many other good places to eat in Madison without being made to feel like you're unwelcome.

This place is pretty standard for Ramen. I ordered the miso Ramen and I was content with it... I did think it was a bit too much that I had to pay extra for their spice bomb, which is basically a little dish for Sriracha. Their sake was pretty good, the bottles were kind of pricey for not that much in it. Overall the atmosphere was chill and the service was pretty good. I just don't think the food was anything that stuck out to me.
The food was great! The staff was not. nice decor. There is on street parking which is usually available. Downside is it does't open until 4

I had tried Umami's dumplings and buns at the Willy St fair this summer and they were awesome so I was excited to finally check out the restaurant and try the ramen. I am not a ramen aficionado, but, I really enjoyed what I had at Umami. I ordered their special and unfortunately I don't remember the name but I believe it had a pork (and maybe chicken?) broth base with pork belly, the noodles obviously, some veggies, nori and an egg. The portion was HUGE and I ended up taking about half home with me and it was delicious the next day for lunch. Had I known how much they give you we may have skipped the chicken and mushroom dumplings for an appetizer...but then again, maybe not, as they were delicious!

Delicious surprise!  Anytime I'm out of town, I search for a hip local restaurant to try out.  After a long search around Yelp, nothing quite grabbed me....just a lot of steak and cheese curds. Luckly I found Umami during a last min Google maps search!  Outside, super cute, looks like you're walking into a house!  Inside, just as cute, very cozy!  There was a wait on a Saturday night of course, but we got a seat at the bar quite quick!  Bartender was amazing, she really knew her stuff and was making awesome drinks in seconds!  Food came out quick too!  I frequent ramen shops, and what really made this stand out from other places was the flavor infused eggs, spicy bomb and garlic bomb.  I freakin' love eggs, these were some of the best ever!  And the broth....I should have worn stretchy pants.  I try not to drink all my broth because I know how high the salt content can get.....not going to happen here.  I made sure every kernel of corn and every bit of scallion made it to my mouth!  The mantou buns were equally amazing!  Some of the fluffiest I have ever had, no wonder they are such a big hit.  I made sure to acquire a t-shirt with the happy pig hanging out in a bun.  Folks back home so jelly...  We wanted to go back the next day, but had to get on the road asap.  We'll be back!

Tried to get a reservation on Friday at 6:30pm for a group of ten. They prefer not to have big groups early but the hostess called me and tried to work it out. We ended up splitting the group up by choice but they were very accommodating. It was very busy but the waitress was very attentive and made sure we were well taken care of.   We always go there for pork buns and ramen and they didn't disappoint. Also love their ginger lychee soda. Must try their dumplings next time.

I saw that this place had Ramen, pork bun, and dumplings and was curious.   There was plenty of dimly lit indoor seating but also outdoor seating facing the street. Watch for the wasps! Parking is available in the back.  Service was great. I was checked on a few times. Drinks and happy hour deals were available.  The pork buns were decent and the bread was not not that thick. It was just enough to cover the ingredients.  I ordered a veggie ramen but I might have been better with the pork-based soup. The noodles were not quite what I expected but for the location, I accept. Perhaps it was the texture of the noodle.  The pork and cabbage dumpling were tasty. They had offered a soy vinegar and  a sweet-and-sour sauce. The skin was thin and held together well.  I wish I had room for the green tea cr√®me br√ªl√©e.   Visa is accepted.

We came to Umami for an earlier dinner, which was nice because it beat the crowd that was to follow. We were able to find street parking (although you may want to just check the lot first) and were quickly seated inside.  Our server for the night was very helpful and attentive, and really answered any questions we had being first timers to Umami. I figured I didn't need my own bowl of ramen, so my boyfriend and I ordered pork buns and dumplings to share, a umami mushroom arugula salad for me, and lastly a big piping hot bowl of ramen for him.   For the food, I have to say that the pork buns were delicious and trumped anything else I tried. If that's the route you want to go, then I may recommend checking out their food cart here in Madison. The dumplings were okay, but didn't stand out as much as the pork buns. My salad was good.  But the real reason people come here is to try the ramen. Overall, I think the ramen was good but was just missing some flavor. We are far from ramen experts and I'd love to try some of the other options on the menu. The bowl was pretty large, so I am glad i went the hodge podge route and ordered a few things to share.  I've heard the brunch menu is amazing, so next time that might be the route we take to try some of their other dishes.

Umami came highly recommended, and the food is fine--but not great by any means.  My problem was really with the service.  Our server took our menus away before we ordered, then came back to take our order (???)  Later, he left our empty plate on the table for a very long time, despite the fact that we were clearly ready to pay the bill and leave...not to mention there was a long wait to be seated.  The real kicker, however, was when I gave him my credit card--which is a Chase Visa card.  It says "Visa" on the back side.  He came back and said "Sorry, we don't take Chase"...and I told him that it was a Visa card.  Seemingly agitated, he said, "WE DON'T TAKE CHASE!"   I gave him another card, he ran the check, and we left...a very modest tip.

The food here is through the roof good. The presentation, the taste, the selection. I have a soft spot for ramen bars and this one does not disappoint. The prices are rather high and I have never left dropping less than $40 on a simple meal, but I was always very satisfied.  I came here for my birthday and Valentine's Day so reservations are a must. This place gets packed even on a weekday so call ahead! I've everything--the lychee mojito, the warmed plum sake, the tonkotsu ramen, the pork belly buns, the mochi ice cream, the potstickers...all out of this world yummy.  Service here is always great and the decor and the cute cocktail glasses are a treat for the eyes.   i think the Pittsburgh equivalent is the Ramen Bar but a quick look at their menu reveals a complete absence of the famed tonkotsu ramen--the best one! So I miss this Madison restaurant a lot, even if I don't miss Madison that much.

If you're expecting Japanese quality ramen then look elsewhere. If you're looking for an alright hot bowl of broth and good noodles and toppings then worth a stop. The dumplings were the biggest disappointment here. Wish I was in Madison longer to try other ramen spots but this wasn't anything special.

After reading my 2 star yelp review, the owner contacted me and offered to comp drink&dessert if I came back.  I came back two months later and the service was very good.  However, the food was still disappointing. The dumplings: I wish they didn't charge for having more than 1 flavor of dipping sauce, and to me, honestly, they didn't taste much better than frozen dumplings and reheating them at home.  The ramen was also disappointing, mostly tasting of salt. I really wanted to like it, but it just wasn't very good.  Desserts were OK--they offered creme brulee or an ice cream sandwich.  The drinks, however, were good, I ordered one of the cocktails they have featured on the menu.  I would go back here for drinks if I was in the area, but nothing else.

We took a chance on this place.  We have been looking for a ramen place since we left Japan.  We spent 3 years in the middle of the heart land...and since then, not been able to find a place that comes close.  This place was close, but not on target.  I will say that the ramen was over priced...very good, but over priced.  This place is more for the small quite bar then their soup.  If you want a unique bar...then this is your place.  if your here for the soup on a cold day...this is not the place.  Service was great by the way.

A fantastic meal for #RestaurantWeek will have me coming back for more! The BBQ Beef buns and and spicy sauce with the dumplings were perfect. It won't matter which dumplings you choose. They are great.  I went wit the Arawe Ramen and it was exquisite. These sent just noodles. They are like manna from heaven.

They ran out of buns the night that we were there. Boo.  The Ramen was ok. They charge you for the hot sauce (don't think it was even house made--maybe just Sriracha?). Really? I mean it should be standard for a bottle of it to be on the table. Their dumplings were SMOTHERED in oil and I am NOT a fan of that.   If we have to be back fine, but trust me I won't be the one to suggest it.

I wasn't really blown away by Umami unfortunately. I thought it was fine...nothing spectacular but certainly edible. I LOVE the outdoor seating and the location but my ramen was actually a bit bland and the chicken in my ramen was beyond tasteless. I will say the broths did have some dimension but it was sort of marred by the bland chicken. The buns were the food highlight for me-I'm a fan of anything with hoisin and the pork in the buns was fantastic!!! Would I go back? Yeah I guess so. Would I be thrilled to be going back? No, not particularly.

Japanese place for breakfast? I was a little skeptical about this place but my wife was really counting on it and we went to this place. I really had the best time ...The bloody mary was out of the world and the steam breakfast buns were really interesting. My wife had mango mimosa which she seemed to enjoy it a lot , but the omu rice she was hoping to taste for a long time was not upto her expectations.

This place is a real gem to have in Madison! Their brunch on the weekends is amazing, and they are the only place in town to serve one of my favorites - Omurice! Absolutely delicious, we will be back and back again just for this dish. Restaurant is small so next time we will definitely make reservations.

We love Willy St & we're looking for a little something with outdoor dining to have a late lunch. Umami looked very charming. Our waitress was so sweet but seemed to forget a few things like water & plates & whether she ordered our ramen or not. But she couldn't have been nicer so it was forgivable.  1st up was the steamed pork buns and the pork dumplings.  The presentation was very nice & the dumplings were really tasty!  I love Chasu Bao and the steamed pork buns were just like it except open.  They were really fresh but had very little taste. It was a bit disappointing.  Then the brunch ramen showed up & bingo!!!  Nirvana!  It made me want to do the Japanese tour on the search for the best ramen noodles in Tokyo.   We shall be back!

We came to eat and there was a 25 minute wait for a 5 top. The place was half empty but only had tables for two available. We returned 25 minutes later and there was no change so they pushed two tables together for us. Then the hostess realized only 4/5 of our party was there. She then said we'd have to wait for the fifth party to join before seating us. He was two blocks away having drinks with a friend. When they told us there'd be a 25 minute wait we told him to take his time. She did not tell us when we first got there that the whole party would need to be present to be seated.

Overall, an enjoyable dinner in a nice atmosphere.  The variety of dinner offerings are quite vast for a rather small menu. Known for dumplings, buns, and ramen, you might have a hard time deciding on which one to choose; so get one of each! That's what we did and were rather pleased. The buns have a pretty weird texture (they look like raw dough?) but are tasty nonetheless.  Don't let the grandma's house appearance from the outside fool you. Inside is done up quite nice with orange walls and soft lighting.  Oh, and the booze. Although this isn't a place I would come running back for a Friday night out, the lychee saketini was a wonderful compliment to the conglomerate of Asian dishes we ordered. Highly recommend.

I personally love Umami! Went the other day and shared the chick and mushroom dumplings, a salad, pork buns and summer rolls. I thought it was all great. You guys should teach some other places how to cook pork belly...  YUMMY
Every time we dine here we get exceptional food and service.. Even on busy days its well worth our wait! Enjoy

This gets a full on YAAAASSSSS KWEEEEEEEEN! from me. We started out with the tuna poke and the pork dumplings. The poke was really nice and fresh, and all the flavors melded together so nicely. The wonton chips tasted homemade, and the slaw and the seaweed salad were so good together. The dumplings were your standard pork dumplings. They didn't really stand out for me, but they were good.  The plan was to try multiple items on the menu, but we got hung up on the pork buns. THE PORK BUNS, GANG!!  I actually cashed out my 401K to buy more pork buns. So good. The bun itself has a marvelous texture. Light and fluffy, and a perfect vehicle for the filling. The pork and hoisin combined with the cucumbers and scallions was beautiful. So beautiful that I changed my son's name to Pork Bun the next day. And then brought him here for a pork bun, so he could experience the gloriousness for himself.  I could eat myself sick on these pork buns. And that's all you need to know.

Brunch. Ramen. A house in Wisconsin.  While this sounds like a badly done MadLib, Umami is real, and it is very nice. It made me extremely nostalgic for Portland or Eugene's food scene.   We went here for brunch after a wedding, where in true Wisconsin fashion, the Spotted Cow flowed and the Death's Door poured. So, we were in pain, and the typical brunch sounded awful. No pancakes or Bloody Marys please.  I had the vegetarian breakfast ramen at Umami, and it was great! The only concern I had was that it could have been slightly spicier; but seeing as how it was a miso flavored soup, it makes sense. A new ramen option for brunch with a spicy broth would be great! The waiter was very attentive and kind (probably due to my brunch partner's moans of lager-induced pain) and even gave me an extra egg! The smoked eggs are DELICIOUS, by the way.   Speaking of, my poor partner swore he was too ill to eat anything and just sipped his tea. The waiter kindly recommended the brunch dumplings, which were eaten soundly and enjoyed. Bacon and dumplings, how could one go wrong.   The outside patio, where we sat, was very lovely, underneath trees. We felt like we were at a friend's house. The inside seemed dark though; probably very nice for dinner, but we were happy to be on the porch.   We recommended this place to my brother and SIL in Madison, as SIL is a California transplant and misses her some ramen.
Atmosphere **** Pork Buns **** (but overpriced) Dumplings *** Ramen * (sorry, but it was terrible, horribly overpriced) Drinks & Service ***

We came here on a busy night. It is a small area for waiting but service was good. The hostess got our drink order pretty fast while we waited. I got the mango mojito which was a little on the sweet side. The wait for a table was very long but we didn't have a problem sitting at the bar which was faster. The bartender took our orders and she was great at explaining the menu. We got the tonkatsu ramen and pork belly buns. The pork belly was way too fatty and I know it is suppose to be fatty but there was barely any meat on it. The buns were nice and soft though. And I've had ramen and pork belly other places and never experienced it that fatty. The broth of the ramen was also insanely salty; and I am an over-salter, I love salt. But even for me it was a little much. Service was really good though. We might come back to try the dumplings but probably not because there are now 2 other ramen places in Madison to give a try and if I want dumplings there are other places to go for just that.

4.5 rating overall!   Service - 4 We went on a Saturday evening 6pm. It was crowded and there was barely any space to stand. We got our seats in like 25-30 mins, the waitress was sweet she handed us the drinks menu while we wait.   Food- 4.5   I loved the pork belly sandwich! Must try it! One won't be enough!! They were scrumptious! I had the pork Raman with garlic shot and spicy shot, I would recommend to order 1 shot between 2 people since the portion is good enough and it's $1 extra for the flavor shots. Raman was really tasty and the pork was very tender and very well spiced.. for dessert we had green tea creme br√ªl√©e , it was absolutely delicious, there was no bitter taste of green tea as I assumed it would have, I would say it was one the best creme br√ªl√©e I have had! Overall this place is great and I will definitely be going there again!!

I've been here twice now. I wasn't too impressed the first time, so I gave it another shot.   I ordered the Tonkatsu with Shiitake Mushrooms. They charge for any extras you have, which is pretty standard of most ramen places, I think. The broth was flavorful, but pretty salty, so I didn't drink the broth after eating the contents of my bowl.  The spicy pulled pork buns are delicious! I find it hard to justify paying that much for two buns, but it was pretty darn good.  I got a Thai Iced Tea. It wasn't too sweet and kind of watered down, to be honest. Hopefully it isn't always like that.  Service was excellent.

When you are in Madison, you must stop by this restaurant. I came here 3 days in a row on a recent business trip because the food and drinks were so amazing. Umami is a hip restaurant with an artsy decorated interior. It is a small place converted from a house but, there is plenty of seating at the bar, indoors, or the outside porch area. They have a unique brunch and dinner menu of food and cocktails with an Asian flare and a modern twist. The pork buns are what kept me coming back everyday. The green tea creme br√ªl√©e and white ice saketini are also worth noting. The quality of food here is top notch. The service is also very good and consistent. I highly recommend Umami and it's roaming food truck if you enjoy eating delicious food and decadent drinks. You will not be disappointed.

My first Umami experience was with a great group of fellow Yelpers, which is the perfect way to experience this place as they have a menu conducive to sharing.   While I'm usually not big on the pickled vegetable concept, the seasonal vegetables pickled in sweet rice wine vinegar were admittedly good. They had just the right amount of vinegary saltiness to them and retained their crunch and vibrant color. They were a healthy sort of tasty and visually appetizing.  We also tried the tuna poke, which was a sashimi grade ahi tuna with seaweed salad and apple cucumber slaw with sweet soy and wonton chips. I love appetizers like these and it was indeed good at Umami. A flavorful, yet light way to welcome in the meal.  We of course tried the dumplings and the three sauces: soy vinegar, sweet, and spicy. These were quality. The skin/dough portion was pleasantly thinner than I was expecting and stuffed with much more delicious meat than I had anticipated.   You definitely can't forget the steamed buns. You know they're good when Umami has a food cart dedicated just to these buns. The melt in your mouth pork belly is my personal favorite, but you can't go wrong with any. The bun itself is served warm and is oh so pillowy. And whether its oven roasted house cured pork belly, koren bbq beef, or fried tofu, they don't skimp on the filling.   As my main course, I ordered the Umami mushroom arugula salad with shiitake, baby portabello and button mushrooms, red onions, cucumber, and cherry tomato. I also added smoked tofu and a garlic bomb, which is a puree of roasted and powdered garlic. Yep, it's a few full tablespoons worth of pure garlic nirvana. While the salad was smaller in terms of salads, I left satisfied thanks to the intense flavors of the dish.
